Autoimmune hemolytic anemia, warm antibody type
Autoimmune hemolytic anemia, cold agglutinin type

Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE): This is an autoimmune disease that can affect many parts of the body, including the joints, blood, and kidneys. It can cause synovitis (inflammation of the joint lining), thrombocytopenia (low blood platelet count), arthropathy (joint pain and swelling), autoimmune hemolysis (destruction of red blood cells by the bodys immune system), and fever. SLE is often treated with corticosteroids and other immunosuppressive medications.

Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA): This is another autoimmune disease that mainly affects the joints. It can cause synovitis, thrombocytopenia (less commonly), and arthropathy. RA is treated with disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs (DMARDs) and biologic agents.

Septic Arthritis: This is an infection of a joint, typically caused by bacteria or fungi. It can cause synovitis, fever, pain, and swelling of the affected joint. Septic arthritis is treated with antibiotics.

Crystalline Arthritis: This type of arthritis is caused by crystals, such as uric acid crystals or calcium pyrophosphate crystals, that build up in the joints. It can cause synovitis, pain, and swelling. Crystalline arthritis is treated with anti-inflammatory medications or corticosteroids.

Lyme Disease: This is an infectious disease caused by the bacterium Borrelia burgdorferi. It can cause a characteristic rash called erythema migrans, as well as fever, fatigue, and joint pain. Lyme disease can also cause acrodermatitis chronicum atrophicans (ACA), which can cause skin atrophy and arthralgias. Lyme disease is treated with antibiotics.

Post-Infectious Arthritis: This is a type of arthritis that can develop after an infection, such as strep throat or chickenpox. It can cause synovitis, pain, and swelling of the affected joints. Post-infectious arthritis usually goes away on its own, but it can be treated with anti-inflammatory medications or corticosteroids.

Adult-Onset Stills Disease: This is a rare inflammatory disease that can cause fever, rash, joint pain, and swelling. It can also cause other symptoms, such as sore throat, fatigue, and abdominal pain. Adult-onset Stills disease is treated with corticosteroids and other immunosuppressive medications.

Serum Sickness: This is a type of immune reaction that can occur after exposure to certain medications or other substances. It can cause fever, rash, joint pain, and swelling. Serum sickness is usually treated with corticosteroids.

Henoch-Schonlein Purpura (HSP): This is a condition that causes inflammation of the blood vessels. It can cause a rash, joint pain, abdominal pain, and kidney problems. HSP is usually treated with corticosteroids.

Parvovirus B19 Infection: This is a common viral infection that can cause a rash, fever, and joint pain. It is usually mild and goes away on its own, but it can be more serious in pregnant women or people with weakened immune systems.
